options.B: The line of Brodel is an important access route for renal surgeries

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true concerning a live-donor kidney transplant?

options.A: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site
options.B: The renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end to the external iliac artery
options.C: The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the internal iliac vein
options.D: Right kidney is preferred over the left for transplantation

questions.explanation: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site chosen for transplantation of thekidney.The left kidney is preferred for transplantation because the left renal vein is longer.In the case of a deceased donor, the arterial graft is traced until the aorta which makes it longer,and hence end-to-side anastomosis is possible. Whereas, in the case of a live donor, the arterialgraft cannot be extended until the aorta.The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live anddeceased donors.Deceased donorEnd-to-sideExternal or common iliLive donorAnastomosisRecipient vesselEnd-to-endInternal iliacSac878Kidney transplantation anastomosesEnd-to-endanastomosisfor live donorkidneyInternaliliac vesselsOMARROWCommoniliac vesselsEnd-to-sideanastomosisfor deceaseddonor kidney

questions.question: An intravenous pyelogram done for evaluation of recurrent UTI in a child is shown below.Which of the following is false regarding this condition?45 MINPRONER4cm868

options.A: Associated with an increased incidence of renal cell carcinoma
options.C: Lies just below the origin of inferior mesenteric artery
options.D: Division at the level of the isthmus improves function

questions.explanation: The given scenario with intravenous pyelogram showing flower vase sign points to a diagnosis ofhorseshoe kidney. Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is usually notindicated. This is because it can lead to an increased risk of urinary fistula.Horseshoe kidneys are the most common fusion defects of the kidney, characterized byabnormalities in the position, rotation, and vascular supply of the kidney.The fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferiormesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery.Adrenal glands remain in the normal position.There is a 2:1 male predominance. It is also commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma,Wilms tumor, multicystic dysplastic kidney, and Turner's syndrome.Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with:• Dull renal pain•Abdominal lump•• Urinary tract infections• Increased angulation of ureters resulting in -• Nephrolithiasis• HydronephrosisRadiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows flower vase sign or handshakesign.Symptomatic management is preferred. Heminephrectomy is usually not indicated for horseshoekidneys with unilateral RCC/ Wilms tumor. This is because it can result in devascularisation dueto the unpredictable blood supply of the horseshoe kidney from nearby major vessels.879Note: Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is only indicated in thecourse of surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm.Horseshoe kidneyOMARROWThe below CECT shows a fusion defect of the kidneys.AortaHorseshoekidneyRenalarteryUreterInferiormesentericartery

questions.question: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed adilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis ofa duplex kidney.It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incompletefusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalycealsystems draining single renal parenchyma.880The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has anectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site ofinsertion (Weigert-Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC.Intravenous urogram shows reversed 'J'/ fish hook ureter.Duplex kidneyRightWeigert-Meyer ruleLeftMARIUpperpole ureterLowerpole ureterOMARROWOpening of ureterfrom inferiorrenal pelvisOpening of ureterfrom superiorrenal pelvis

questions.question: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent left-sided flank pain. His brother passedaway two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below.Which of the following is false regarding his condition?869kv 120rk 200Srart rA 200

options.A: Decompression of cyst improves renal function

questions.explanation: The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis ofadult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In such patients, decompression or deroofing of thecysts (Rovsing's procedure) cannot restore normal renal function.ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16)and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4).The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is neverdiagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males.Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:• Flank/loin pain - either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonlyuric acid stones)• Irregular upper quadrant renal mass•• Hematuria• Uremia• Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces dueto multiple cysts. Nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presenceof either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD.881Treatment includes:• Long-term dialysis• Renal transplantation•• Vasopressin V2 receptor antagonistsAutosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) occurs secondary to a mutation of thePKHD1 gene. The severe form manifests in-utero or during infancy; milder cases can manifestlater in childhood. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.

questions.question: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. Whatis the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junctionpoints to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or completeblockage of urinary flow.Investigations:• Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.• Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction beforecorrective surgery.• Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, theextrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, thereis blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages.• A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatationof the collecting system.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: An ultrasound scan done at 32 weeks for a woman with oligohydramnios revealed fetalhydronephrosis. What is the most likely cause for this condition?
questions.explanation: Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis found onprenatal ultrasound.•The causes of UPJ obstruction can be:• Intrinsic - due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter• Extrinsic - due to accessory renal arteriesTreatment includes Anderson Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty.Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis. InVUR, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective.Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from thepersistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. IVU shows cobrahead/ adder head appearance.882Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as aresult of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outletobstruction in male newborns.Note: Renal stones are the most common cause of acquired unilateral hydronephrosis.

questions.question: A mother brings her 3-month-old infant to the OPD with complaints of him crying whileurinating. On palpation, a left-sided flank mass is felt. A USG KUB revealed dilation of thepelvicalyceal system with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the investigation ofchoice to confirm his diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction. The investigation ofchoice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Delayed clearanceof contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction.Renal isotope scans have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice inUPJ obstruction.• 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects thetubular function.• 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function. Hence, it iscommonly used to assess GFR.In obstructive uropathy, 99mTc-DTPA is the preferred isotope as glomerular function declinesearlier and more rapidly than tubular function.Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux.Tc-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring.Note: In children, crying before and after micturition is usually considered normal. While cryingduring micturition is usually suggestive of pathology.

questions.question: A child was brought to you with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain. USG revealedleft-sided hydronephrosis. On the third follow-up day, a decrease in abdominal pain wasnoted after he passed a large amount of urine. Repeat USG showed a significant decrease inthe size of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario of hydronephrosis with renal pain relieved after the passage of a large amountof urine is suggestive of Dietl's crisis.It is defined as intermittent ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction causing episodic abdominalpain and nausea, most often due to an aberrant accessory renal artery or vein.In an acute phase of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, loin swelling occurs along withrenal pain due to the retention of urine in the kidney. When the obstruction is relieved, thepatient passes a large amount of urine, the swelling is reduced and the pain disappears. This istermed Dietl's crisis.In the majority of cases, pyeloplasty results in the complete resolution of symptoms.

questions.question: Which of the following are risk factors for calcium stone formation?
questions.explanation: Hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hyperuricosuria are risk factors for calcium stone formation.883Risk factors for calcium stone formation include:•High urine concentration of calcium, oxalate, or uric acid• Low urine concentration of renal stone inhibiting factors such as citrate and magnesium• Abnormal urine pHRenal stone formation is governed by factors promoting and inhibiting stone formation. Stoneformation occurs when the concentration product is more than the formation product i.e., CP >FP, where:•Concentration product (CP) - the amount of solute in solution• Formation product (FP) - maximum concentration of solute in solution after taking into accountstone inhibiting factors.

questions.question: Which among the following is the investigation of choice in a patient suspected to haveureteric stones?
questions.explanation: Non-contrast CT abdomen (NCCT) is the investigation of choice for the clinical evaluation ofureteric stones.NCCT is the preferred investigation for evaluation of:• Renal stones except for indinavir stones• Ureteric stones• Head injury•Salivary gland stones

questions.question: A man presents to the casualty with fever and hematuria for 3 days. He also gives a history ofrecurrent left-sided loin pain radiating to the groin. X-ray KUB done is shown below. Whichof the following is false regarding stones seen in his condition?R872

options.A: Composed of calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate
options.B: It is formed in acidic urine
options.C: Increased risk with infections by urease producing organisms
options.D: Rectangular or coffin lid appearance on microscopy

questions.explanation: The given scenario and X-Ray KUB showing staghorn appearance points to a diagnosis of struvitestones. Struvite stone is produced in alkaline urine.It is commonly associated with infections with urea-splitting organisms like Proteus andKlebsiella species. Increased metabolism of urea results in alkalinity of the urine.Struvite is a triple-phosphate calculus (calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate). Thecalculus may enlarge to fill most of the collecting system, forming a staghorn calculus.These stones are dirty-white in color, and grossly smooth in texture. Rectangular or coffinlid appearance is seen on microscopic examination.

questions.question: Acetohydroxamic acid will be prescribed for patients with which of the following types ofrenal stones?
questions.explanation: Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone.884It is a urease inhibitor. The urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of theurine. This favors the production of struvite stones. Thus, the use of AHA(Acetohydroxamic acid)causes complete, noncompetitive inhibition of urease production, thereby slowing struvite stonegrowth. Owing to its side-effects, the use of this drug has been restricted in cases of recurrentUTIS, and those intolerant or who refuse surgical management.It can also be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.

questions.question: A patient is referred for the evaluation of severe right-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal X-rayappears normal, and a USG revealed the presence of a 6mm renal stone. Which of thefollowing stones is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone.Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated withdisorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopicexamination, the crystals appear as glass shards.Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol.Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.

questions.question: The urine microscopy of a young man admitted for the evaluation of renal stones shows thefollowing finding. What type of stone is this?873
questions.explanation: The urine microscopy shows the presence of hexagonal-shaped stones which are likely to becystine stones.These stones are commonly found in acidic urine. Recurrent stones are treated usingD-penicillamine.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding renal stones?

options.A: A low calcium diet can prevent the recurrence of calcium stone
options.B: Potassium citrate reduces the risk of uric acid stone
options.C: d-Penicillamine can be used to prevent cystine stone formation
options.D: Pyridoxine can reduce the risk of oxalate stone formation

questions.explanation: A low calcium diet has not shown any significant benefit in the prevention of calcium stoneformation, compared to a normocalcemic diet.However, a diet rich in calcium rather binds with dietary oxalate and reduces dietary absorptionof oxalate. This effect leads to a lower risk of calcium oxalate stone formation in the kidneys.Option B: Uric acid crystallization and stone formation take place in acidic pH. Therefore, urinaryalkalinization by potassium citrate reduces the risk of urate stone formation.Option C: Cystine stones are usually formed in presence of cystinuria. Initial treatment options toprevent recurrent cystine stone formation includes increased fluid intake and urinaryalkalinization (e.g citrate). If this therapy fails, d-penicillamine can be used.Option D: Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor in the oxalic acid metabolism process and helps in thereduction of endogenous oxalate levels. Several studies have mentioned the role of pyridoxine inthe reduction of oxalate stone formation.885
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

questions.question: An HIV-positive man on HAART presents to the casualty with intermittent right-sided flankpain. He is suspected to have renal stones. Which of the following drugs is most likely to beresponsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Indinavir (a protease-inhibitor) is most likely to be responsible for renal stones in a patient onHAART. It has the highest incidence of nephrolithiasis among anti-retroviral drugs.Indinavir is released in high concentration in the urine due to poor solubility in the physiologicpH. Consequently, patients develop stones that are principally composed of indinavir or of amixture of indinavir and other substances, such as calcium oxalate.•Other urolithogenic drugs are:Antihypertensives - furosemide, bumetanide (loop diuretics), triamterene (potassium-sparingdiuretic)• Decongestant - ephedrine•Expectorant - guaifenesin•Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - acetazolamide, topiramate, and zonisamide⚫ Newer antiretroviral agents - lopinavir-ritonavir, ritonavir-boosted atazanavir, nelfinavir, andamprenavir

questions.question: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse?
questions.explanation: Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases theproduction of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemiaand reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid andammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones.These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrenturinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation.The below image shows an ammonium urate stone.886

questions.question: A woman with severe right-sided colicky loin pain is suspected to have renal calculi. What isthe maximum size of the calculi up to which this patient can be managed expectantly?
questions.explanation: Patients with renal calculi ≤ 0.5 cm in size can be treated expectantly, as they are likely to passspontaneously.Medical management of renal stones involves:• Pain control with NSAIDS or opioid analgesics•• Medical expulsive therapy with tamsulosin (a blocker) and Nifedipine (calcium channel blockers)•Monitoring for the symptoms of urinary tract infection and decreased renal function

questions.question: In patients with which of the following renal stones, will extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsynot be considered?
questions.explanation: Cystine stones are very hard stones, hence it is difficult to disintegrate it with extracorporealshockwave lithotripsy (ESWL).ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focusedon the stones. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.Stones that are difficult to disintegrate by ESWL:• Cystine• Brushite• Calcium oxalate monohydrateStones that are relatively easy to disintegrate by ESWL:•Calcium oxalate dihydrate•Phosphate

questions.question: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy is contraindicated in all of the following patientsexcept?

options.A: A young woman with untreated bleeding diathesis
options.C: A man with a ureteric stricture875
options.D: A middle aged man with a saccular aneurysm

questions.explanation: Saccular aneurysm or berry aneurysm is not a contraindication for extracorporeal shockwavelithotripsy (ESWL).Contraindications to ESWL:• Pregnancy• Uncorrected coagulopathy or bleeding diathesis• Untreated urinary tract infection•• Arterial aneurysm near stones (renal or abdominal aortic aneurysms)• Obstruction of urinary tract distal to the stones887• Skeletal malformations resulting in an inability to target stonesComplications of ESWL include:• Pain• Hematuria•Steinstrasse - means a street of stones. It occurs due to the collection of stone fragments in theureter•Urinary tract infections

questions.question: An elderly woman was brought to the hospital with a history of severe loin pain for the past 7hours. Ultrasound of the kidney reveals a 2.5 cm renal stone. What is the treatment of choicefor this patient?
questions.explanation: The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size >2cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy(PCNL).In PCNL, endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique, andstones are removed. PCNL is also indicated in:•Staghorn calculi•Multiple stones• Proximal ureteral stones >1 cmComplications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include hemorrhage, perforation of the collectingsystem, and of the colon or pleural cavity.Another approach for the management of renal stones is ureteroscopic removal (URS)or retrograde intra-renal surgery (RIRS). In URS, stones are removed via a retrograde approachusing a dormia basket, or a Holmium YAG laser is used to break the stones.If PCNL or URS fails, open or laparoscopic pyelolithotomy or nephrolithotomy is done.The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy.Dormia basket and ureteroscopicrenal stone removal.BasketintroducedOpenedEnclosing stone,past stoneready forwithdrawalMARROW888

questions.question: A man came to the casualty with right-sided colicky loin pain radiating to the inner thigh.NCCT abdomen revealed a non-impacted 1cm calculi in the right ureter. How will youmanage this patient?
questions.explanation: Ureteroscopic removal is the preferred treatment in non-impacted ureteric stones >5-6mm insize.

questions.question: A man was brought to the casualty with severe left-sided colicky flank pain. On examination,he was febrile, with a BP of 90/60 mmHg and a feeble rapid pulse. Investigations revealedWBC= 16,800 with a 2.5 cm calculi in the left ureter. What is the preferred management inthis patient?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a patient in sepsis secondary to an obstructed renal calculi.Nephrostomy is the preferred management in these patients.Treatment in patients with sepsis secondary to an obstructing urinary tract calculi includes:• Insertion of a percutaneous nephrostomy• Insertion of a ureteric stent via cystoscopyNephrostomy is preferred in extremely unwell patients as it is less manipulative and has a lowerrisk of septicemia.889
